III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112
Section Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff qualifications
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation There are concerns that a staff member has been providing youth
with a vape pen while on therapeutic outing. The youth are taken
into the bathroom multiple times when they use the vape. A
search of the youth's room was conducted and a vape pen was
not located.
Investigation Complainant was contacted on 8/6/2025, 8/19/25, and 9/2/25.
Complainant denied ever seeing Staff 1 with a vape and reported
the information had been disclosed to them by a youth.
Complainant also denied witnessing Staff 1 give any youth a vape
pen or any contraband. Complainant had no additional information
and reported no concerns.
Consumers Advocate (CA) was interviewed on 8/11/2025 face
to face in collaboration with MDHHS and by email on
8/20/2025. CA reported Staff 1 works the afternoon shift at Vista
Maria and had been placed on administrative leave pending the
investigation. CA further confirmed Staff 1 was employed at the
facility at the end of May 2025. She did not begin interacting with
youth until June 4, 2025. Therefore, according to CA, it would not
have been possible for Staff 1 to provide any youth with a vape in
April, which is when the incident was reported to have occurred.
Youth A was interviewed face to face on 08/06/2025 at Vista
Maria by MDHHS worker. The licensing consultant
participated by phone. MDHHS worker proceeded with the
interview due to Youth A’s scheduled home visit on this day.
During the interview, Youth A reported not wanting to speak with
the MDHHS worker. Youth A denied the allegations and reported
never seeing youth or staff use or possess vapes. Youth A also
denied any staff member had given vapes to her or any other
youth. Youth A refused to answer additional questions but
reported feeling safe at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face to face on 8/11/2025 at Vista
Maria in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B reported
being placed at Vista Maria for approximately 11 months. Youth B
reported not seeing Staff 1 with a vape pen and had not witnessed
Staff 1 give a vape pen to other youth at the facility. Youth B
2

denied the incident and stated that none of her peers told her they
had vapes. Youth B also denied staff had given her or any other
youth vapes during outings.
Youth C was interviewed face to face on 8/11/2025 at Vista
Maria in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C reported
being placed at Vista Maria for four months and reported feeling
safe. Youth C reported having a tobacco vape while placed at
Vista Maria, with the first instance occurring in April. She reported
not telling any of her peers. Youth C reported Staff 1 and several
other staff took her and some other youth on an outing to a park,
though she could not remember the date or the name of the park.
During the outing, Youth C reported seeing a vape pen inside
Staff 1’s open purse. She reported telling Staff 1, "You be smoking
that shit, don't you?" and said Staff 1 smiled. Youth C reported
asking if she could hit the vape. According to Youth C, Staff 1
initially said no, then told her, "Come on, let's go in the bathroom
so you can hit that.” Youth C reported she and Staff 1 walked
alone into the bathroom at the park, where she hit the vape
several times. She reported it was a tobacco vape, not a
marijuana vape. Youth C reported no one witnessed the incident
and she could not recall which residents or staff were present on
the outing. She reported the incident occurred only once and no
other staff or youth had a vape or gave youth a vape.
Youth D was interviewed face to face on 8/11/2025 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth D denied seeing
anyone with a vape at the facility. Youth D reported never seeing
youth or staff with vapes and had not seen Staff 1 with a vape pen
or any other contraband.
Staff 1 was interviewed on 8/20/25 via telephone in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 1 reported working the
afternoon shift at Vista Maria and has been employed since May.
Staff 1 denied smoking vape pens and reported never going into a
bathroom with Youth C or with other youth during outings. She
reported smoking cigarettes and reported whenever she needed
to smoke, she went across the street from the facility, in
accordance with company policy. Staff 1 denied ever seeing vape
pens or contraband on campus and denied witnessing youth or
staff in possession of vape pens or contraband. She reported the
allegations were false and reported she would never supply youth
with vape pens. Staff 1 also reported, although she smokes
cigarettes, she does not bring them onto the premises or inside
the building.
3

Staff 2 and Staff 3 were interviewed face to face on 8/11/25 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Staff 2 reported being
employed at the facility since September 2024 as a youth coach.
She reported Staff 1 worked the afternoon shift while she worked
the morning shift. Staff 2 denied ever seeing any staff give youth
contraband or vape pens and also denied seeing any staff or
youth use or discuss vape pens.
According to Staff 3, Youth C disclosed she observed Staff 1 use
a vape pen on 8/10/2025. Staff 3 also reported overhearing Youth
C tell another staff member about Staff 1 bringing in a vape pen.
Staff 3 reported room searches are completed every day and that
a room search was completed and no vape pens were found. She
denied ever working with Staff 1 and denied seeing youth or staff
with vape pens or witnessing staff give youth contraband.
Staff 4, Staff 5, Supervisor 2 , Supervisor 3, Therapist 1, and
Therapist 2 were interviewed via telephone on 9/2/2025.
Staff 4 reported being employed at Vista Maria for one year and
stated she had been on campus walks with Staff 1. Staff 4
reported not seeing Staff 1 or any other staff with a vape pen. She
further denied ever observing Staff 1 or any staff give youth
contraband or vape pens. Staff 4 reported that a few weeks prior,
Youth A became upset and reported Staff 1 had given another
youth a vape pen. Room searches were conducted following the
report, and no vape pens were found.
Staff 5 reported working the morning shift and not working the
same shift as Staff 1, who worked the afternoon shift. She
reported going on outings with the youth but never seeing them
with vapes. Staff 5 reported having no concerns about Staff 1 or
any other staff.
Supervisor 2 reported being employed with Vista Maria for 10
years. Supervisor 2 reported she did not work the same shift as
Staff 1 and had never seen youth or staff with a vape pen.
Supervisor 3 Supervisor 3 reported while in the office, a staff
member reported Youth B alleged Staff 1 had given youth a vape
pen. Following the allegation, a room search was conducted, and
no vape pens were found. Supervisor 3 denied ever seeing Staff 1
or any other staff use a vape pen or provide contraband to youth.
Supervisor 3 reported having no concerns with Staff 1 and denied
ever observing her violate company policy.
4

Supervisor 1 was interviewed via telephone on 9/3/25 with
MDHHS worker. Supervisor 1 reported being a team leader at
Vista Maria. Supervisor 1 reported being present during the
incident. Supervisor 1 reported he provided direction to Supervisor
3 to complete an incident report after Youth A disclosed Staff 1
gave her a vape pen. Following this allegation, Supervisor 1
reported a room search was completed immediately and no vape
pens were found. Supervisor 1 reported he did not witness Staff 1
or any other staff use a vape pen or provide vape pens to the
youth.
Therapist 1 reported being Youth C’s therapist since July 2025
and providing therapy at least twice weekly. Therapist 1 reported
no youth disclosed Staff 1 or any other staff gave them vapes or
contraband. Therapist 1 reported no concerns regarding Staff 1 or
other staff. Staff 1 reported she had not seen any staff use vapes
or give residents vapes or contraband.
Therapist 2 was interviewed via telephone on 9/2/2025 with the
MDHHS worker. Therapist 2 is assigned to Youth D who denied
any staff giving residents vapes or contraband. Therapist 2
reported no youth made complaints about staff giving them vapes
or contraband and denied ever seeing staff use or possess vapes
or contraband.
A MDHHS Disposition was held on 9/3/25 via Teams.
According to MDHHS worker, there were no findings and Law
enforcement will not be pressing charges against Staff 1.
Documents Reviewed:
Staff 1’s personnel file: There were no disciplinary records and
Staff 1 completed Employee Training guide on 7/10/2025, Safety
Care on 6/25/25, and Six Core Strategies- Direct Care Services
on 06/06/25.
Incident Report #4047 dated 8/11/25 written by Supervisor 3.
The report is consistent with Supervisor 2 interview. The report
documents that no vape pens or contrabands were found.
Incident Report #3999 dated 8/11/25 written by Supervisor 3.
The report was consistent with staff and youth interviews.
Incident report #4001 dated 8/5/2025 written by Staff 5 and
Supervisor 1 was consistent with youth and staff interviews.
Off Campus Activity Policy:
Check-in and Check-out Procedures is as follows:
5

Before clients enter any area beyond the foyer after returning from
an off-campus activity or home pass, or before leaving the foyer to
go to an activity/home pass, staff must conduct client checks
following these steps:
1. Keep all clients returning or leaving within sight at all times
until the check-in/check-out process is complete.
2. Refer to the list of contraband in the Program Handbook as
needed.
3. Inspect the contents of all bags and personal items.
4. Ensure the client empties all pockets for inspection.
5. Ask the client to remove shoes and socks and shake out or
show inside.
6. Ask the client to pull out the waistband of their pants to
confirm nothing is tucked in.
7. Ask the client to lift the bottom of their bra band outward
enough to verify no items are hidden.
8. Retain any contraband found and complete an Incident
Report.
Additional Notes:
• Staff must ensure clients are not wearing multiple layers of
clothing to conceal items.
• During outings, staff conduct random head counts to
maintain safety and security for all participants.
Unit Security Checks Policy: At the beginning of each shift, the
incoming supervisor completes a security check with the departing
supervisor or designee. To ensure client safety, all second-floor
windows must remain locked. The security check verifies that all
items on the unit's checklist are accounted for, all clients are
located, and all areas (e.g., bedrooms, screens, locks, fireboxes,
telephones) are secured. Linen and janitorial closets must remain
locked. During room checks, bedrooms should be observed for
unsafe items or potential risks. Any such items must be removed
and documented in an Incident Report if necessary. If the
supervisor or designee suspects contraband, a full room search
may be initiated (see POL-006-017, Client Privacy). If any security
issues or missing items are identified, the departing supervisor
must remain until the issue is resolved. All concerns must be
documented in the Daily Unit Report and, if needed, in an Incident
Report.
Staff and Client Interaction Policy:
All Vista Maria staff should conduct themselves in a professional
and appropriate manner when interacting with the clients in our
6

care. Employees are expected to establish good working
relationships to foster mutual trust with clients.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance following staff and youth
interviews and given the verified timeline and lack of supporting
evidence. The agency appropriately followed internal procedures,
including room searches, with no contraband found. Youth C
claimed Staff 1 gave her a vape in April; however, employment
records confirm Staff 1 didn’t start until June 2025. Staff 1 denied
the allegation, and no other staff or youth corroborated the claim.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
